author: pcAdminPNG
title: OTML safety manager scoops international women‚Äôs safety award
text:
Ok Tedi Mining Limited‚Äôs (OTML) safety manager Anna Ila was the proud recipient of the Leader of the Year Award at the ‚ÄòWomen in Safety‚Äô Awards in Sydney, Australia on November 27, 2023.
Women in Safety is a network of women who are safety professionals in Australia and the Asia Pacific region.
This network leads discussions on health and safety issues, challenges and improvements, with the aim to make a positive impact resulting in improved outcomes for its members and workplaces.
Scooping this award is a big deal as it is the first for OTML and goes a long way to highlight the importance of the company‚Äôs safety initiatives at the work place, while also showcasing the company‚Äôs commitment to gender diversity and inclusion in all aspects of its operations.
‚ÄúThe recognition that I gained from this award shows the incredible work women are doing in their roles to create change in the safety space to ensure workplaces are safer today than they were yesterday, particularly in mining where the nature of our business is such that our workforce is exposed to risks that can impact their safety and long-term wellbeing,‚Äù Ms Ila said.
Ms Ila‚Äôs award submission showcased key aspects from the OTML‚Äôs 2023 safety plan including building an inclusive working relationship with OTML‚Äôs Business Partners, having a targeted risk based and ‚Äústrategic‚Äù approach in managing safety risk, and a focus on major hazards and behavioural safety.
‚ÄúI would like to thank the OTML management for the recognition and support that ensures I perform my role and lead my team to make OTML a safe workplace for its employees and business partners,‚Äù she said.
‚ÄúCongratulations Anna and we look forward to seeing more women at OTML excel in their respective roles, and especially so in the safety and occupational health arena.
Ms Ila is well placed to lead the Team in the implementation of Ok Tedi‚Äôs plans to continue to improve our safety performance,‚Äù said OTML general manager, people and culture, Mark Stone.
The award event recognises aspiring women in the field of safety. Out of almost 100 outstanding nominations, 24 finalists made it through the selection process.

author: @binederland
title: Attorney for the mom of a 15-year-old school shooter opened her manslaughter trial by quoting Taylor Swift‚Äôs ‚ÄòBad Blood‚Äô
text:
- Jennifer and James Crumbley are facing manslaughter charges for their son's school shooting.
- The case against against the parents is the first of its kind.
- In her opening remarks on Thursday, Jennifer Crumbley's attorney quoted Taylor Swift's "Bad Blood."
In a fist-of-its-kind case, the parents of a 15-year-old school shooter in Michigan are facing manslaughter charges, accused of making a firearm too easily accessible and ignoring warning signs.
And as the high-profile trial got underway on Thursday, the attorney for the mother ‚Äî in a surprising choice ‚Äî warmed up the jury with Taylor Swift Lyrics.
Jennifer Crumbley and her husband James are both charged with involuntary manslaughter after their son carried out a school shooting in Oxford, Michigan in 2021 that left four dead. Both parents
face up to 60 years in prison if convicted.
The Crumbleys originally planned to stand trial together but in November
requested separate trials after prosecutors claimed in court filings that Jennifer Crumbly blamed her husband for the shooting.
Shannon Smith, an attorney for Jennifer Crumbley, began her opening statement to the jury by reciting a Taylor Swift song. Smith told the jury she had "blasted" Swift's music in the car on the way to court in the morning in an effort to "calm her nerves."
Smith said the quote, "Band-Aids don't stop bullet holes" perfectly "summarized what this case is about." She appeared to be quoting Swift's 2014 smash hit "Bad Blood," which says "Band-Aids don't fix bullet holes, you say sorry just for show."
"It's about the prosecution attempting to put a Band-Aid on problems that can't be fixed with a Band-Aid," Smith told the jury.
Smith went on to say that prosecutors had charged Crumbley in an effort to make the community feel better, to send a message to gun owners, and to make it "feel like somebody is being held responsible," none of which can be accomplished by convicting Crumbley, she said.
"In this case, a Band-Aid will never bring back the lives that were lost," Smith said.
Smith told the jury that much of the evidence they would hear and see is "horrific" and would scare them. But she urged the jurors to focus their frustration on Crumbley's son.
Crumbley's son pleaded guilty in October 2022. A judge sentenced him to life in prison without the possibility of parole in December.
Smith also appeared to begin laying some of the blame on the husband, James Crumbley, saying Jennifer didn't keep track of the family's guns. According to Smith, Jennifer Crumbley did not know where the family's gun was kept or "how to put it in the car." Smith told the jury that the family kept the gun in a locked box in the parents' bedroom and that James Crumbley kept the key.
Prosecutor Marc Keast, meanwhile, described Jennifer Crumbley as an unaware mom who had several opportunities to intervene before her 15-year-old murdered his classmates.
Keast presented a math worksheet on which Crumbley's son wrote disturbing messages like "the world is dead" and "my life is useless" that school counselors showed to both parents on the morning of the shooting in an emergency meeting. Keast told the jury that Jennifer Crumbley "abruptly" ended the meeting after just 11 minutes and did not take her son home.
Smith said in court that Jennifer Crumbley intends to take the stand in the trial. Opening statements for James Crumbley's trial are scheduled to begin on March 5.
Business Insider

author: @miapilgrim
title: La playa de interior m√°s espectacular de Espa√±a est√° a dos horas de Madrid, con aguas trasparentes y un intenso color azul turquesa
text: El calor aprieta en verano para todos pero no todos vivimos cerca de la costa, sin embargo, no todos tenemos el mar cerca para refrescarnos. Por suerte, tambi√©n existen [las piscinas naturales](https://www.trendencias.com/viajes/aqui-no-hay-playa-piscinas-naturales-instagrameables-espana-2) en el interior. No obstante, hay un escal√≥n superior a las pozas y los lagos porque las playas de interior existen. De todas ellas, las m√°s espectacular de Espa√±a se encuentra a solo dos horas de Madrid. En Castilla La Mancha, en los l√≠mites de las provincias de Ciudad Real y Albacete, se abre paso un paraje natural protegido que, adem√°s de por su gran belleza, destaca por sus singularidades paisaj√≠sticas y geol√≥gicas. Se trata de las Lagunas de Ruidera, un parque natural formado por quince lagunas que, a lo largo de 30 kil√≥metros, constituyen el valle del Alto Guadiana y, en su parte m√°s alta. se encuentra el lugar de nacimiento del r√≠o Guadiana. Siendo as√≠, no es de extra√±ar que Ruidera sea uno de los parajes naturales m√°s sorprendentes de Espa√±a que recorrer conociendo sus inmensas lagunas de aguas trasparentes e intenso color azul turquesa. Adem√°s, tienen la particularidad de que estas quince lagunas se rebosan e inundan unas a otras formando cascadas y saltos debido a formaciones geol√≥gicas como las barreras travert√≠nicas. Por otro lado, Ruidera es hogar de una gran riqueza biol√≥gica con diversidad de especies animales y plantas, montes de encinares y sabinares, sotos, arboledas de √Ålamos... Lo que supone una nota de frescor y casi un oasis en La Mancha llana y seca. Del mismo modo, todo el que se acerca a conocer este parque natural puede disfrutar del planeo del √Åguila perdicera, y la garza imperial o el Barbo cabecicorto. En las inmediaciones de este parque natural hay disponibles un sinf√≠n de actividades m√°s all√° de [las zonas de ba√±o](https://www.lagunasderuidera.es/zonas-de-ba%C3%B1o_lavisita_54.html), tales como senderismo, buceo, kayak, paddle surf, vela, pesca deportiva... Adem√°s, dada la extensi√≥n de las lagunas de Ruidera (cerca de 3.772 hect√°reas), para poder conocer y disfrutar de este espacio natural en su totalidad [se ofrecen visitas guiadas](https://www.lagunasderuidera.es/visitaguiada.php). Foto de portada | [Adri√°n Rodr√≠guez](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=User:Adrianrodriguezfotografia&action=edit&redlink=1) En Trendencias | [Las 33 escapadas rom√°nticas por Espa√±a para hacer en pareja en las que quiz√° no hab√≠as pensado](https://www.trendencias.com/viajes/27-escapadas-espana-para-hacer-pareja-que-quiza-no-habias-pensado)

author: Novinky.cz
title: Ground News - Zelensky praises Pope: Thanks to Ukrainians, Russian murderers do not march through Europe
text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that Ukrainians are the reason why murderers are not marching through Europe. Zelensky said this in a video message in which he thanked Ukrainian troops and indirectly chastised the pope for his call for Ukraine to fly the white flag. This is reported by the newspaper Ukrainska Pravda. author: Caprice St Pierre; The Canadian Press
title: Oilers back end looks sharp with addition of Walman, return of Ekholm
text:
EDMONTON ‚Äî With a series of trades, the return of an important player and some moves on the blue line, the Edmonton Oilers might have fixed their back end.
Tuesday's 7-1 blowout over Utah Hockey Club showcased some depth scoring to counteract the end of Leon Draisaitl's 18-game point streak, but also some stability on a blue line the Oilers have said they will need for the playoffs.
"I don't want to get ahead of myself too early, but after the break we were rock bottom, we played terrible, we were getting outplayed tremendously," said Oilers head coach Kris Knoblauch. "But we've been getting better and better and it started with our team defence and eliminating chances of the rush. And once you play better defensively, things will work better offensively.
"You saw that (last) night. The way we were back checking, creating turnovers, countering. So we've been getting better these past couple weeks, but certainly more room to go."
The improved performance led to the suggestion that newly acquired defenceman Jake Walman, could be deployed right-side along Darnell Nurse, an idea he seems open to.
"I'm comfortable with that. I think there's opportunities that open up when you're on your off-side," added Walman, who's a left-shot, traditionally left-side defenceman, but has embraced the expectations placed on him north of the border.
"You always want to be ready. There's that standard here, you can feel it just when you walk into the room. I'm excited to be a part of it."
The Oilers say they are "excited" to have him. Almost as much as Mattias Ekholm is excited to be back.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to watch on TV. You want to be part of it. Especially during the stretch coming down here,‚Äù Ekholm said.
The left side defencemen returned from injury just in time to help propel the Oilers to open a four-game homestand with a win.
"He's an exceptional penalty killer, so when he's not there, that's a huge whole," Knoblauch said of Ekholm.
It's not that Knoblauch feels the Oilers penalty kill struggled terribly without Ekholm, but the Swede left a big hole that needed some big shoes to fill.
Ekholm logged a goal and two assists in his "transition" game against Utah, his first since returning from an illness and undisclosed lower-body injury sustained March 4 against the Anaheim Ducks. He also helped guide a defensively struggling Evan Bouchard, who had an assist, on the top defensive pairing.
That was the value the Oilers have felt Ekholm could bring to the lineup ‚Äî a guy that can direct players into the slot and manage the rest of the blue line.
"He's able to defend extremely well, but also get Leon (Draisaitl) and Connor (McDavid) on good breakout passes," Knoblauch explained.
"He's a guy that's able to play other teams top units, as a shutdown guy. But able to also play with our top guys and be able to transfer the puck. He's a not make a mistake kind of guy."
Looking into what the Oilers hope is another long playoff stretch, a "not make a mistake guy" should be a key factor in leading the defence as the team looks to transitioning from a 3-3-0 start to March ‚Äî which included a loss to the lowly Buffalo Sabres ‚Äî into the team that now sits four points out of top spot in the Pacific Division.
"The six of us as a group, as we continue to get more and more chemistry and mesh, it's really exciting to look at our back end and be a part of it," Nurse said.
Nurse showed he could again a beast on the blue line after winning a fight against Jack McBain with seconds left and two goals up in the first period.
"I was just hitting, nothing really (going on)," Nurse said.
There's no guarantee that the rowdy performance will carry on, but it brings back some of that physicality Knoblauch has been talking about for weeks.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published March 19, 2025.
Caprice St. Pierre, The Canadian Press

author: Sky TG24
title: Usa, onde gigantesche in California: aree evacuate | Sky TG24
text: Onde anche di sei metri stanno flagellando da ore la costa californiana, provocando allagamenti e distruzione di strutture balneari. La tempesta ha messo in fuga molte persone che si godevano gli ultimi giorni dell'anno con passeggiate lungo le spiagge - Le coste della California sono flagellate da ieri da onde alte fino a sei metri che stanno provocando danni e allagamenti soprattutto alle strutture balneari [Onu: ‚Äú12mila disastri meteo e 2 milioni di vittime in 50 anni‚Äù](https://tg24.sky.it/ambiente/2023/05/22/meteo-cambiamento-climatico-eventi-vittime-onu) [](#02) - Diverse le persone messe in fuga dall'aggravarsi della situazione, soprattutto i vacanzieri che si godevano gli ultimi giorni dell‚Äôanno a passeggiare lungo le spiagge [Disastri naturali in Italia: 35 miliardi di danni in 10 anni](https://tg24.sky.it/ambiente/2023/10/20/cambiamento-climatico-italia-danni-costo) [](#03) - Le prime anomalie si sono registrate ieri lungo Ventura Beach, una delle mete pi√π popolate in questi giorni, tra Los Angeles e Santa Barbara [Film apocalittici sui disastri naturali: quali vedere](https://tg24.sky.it/spettacolo/cinema/approfondimenti/film-apocalittici) [](#04) - Muri sono stati abbattuti nel sud della California. Una ventina di persone sono state colte di sorpresa dalle onde, otto sono state ricoverate in ospedale per ferite [](#06) - Alcune aree vicine all'oceano sono state evacuate. Le immagini delle onde gigantesche sono diventate virali sui social [Terremoti, scossa di magnitudo 4.8 a confine tra California e Messico](https://tg24.sky.it/mondo/2023/12/01/terremoto-california-oggi)

author: Anonym
title: Premier League: Arsenal fall to West Ham and miss chance to take the lead - The Limited Times
text:
A small feat for West Ham and a setback for the Gunners! By winning (0-2) at the Emirates Stadium, Alphonse Areola and his teammates stunned Arsenal on Thursday evening, at the end of the 19th day of the Premier League.
The Gunners needed to win to move ahead of Liverpool, take the lead in the league and at the same time distance Manchester City and Unai Emery's Aston Villa. But Mikel Arteta's men lacked realism as evidenced by the statistics of the match: 74.2% possession in their favour, 30 shots including eight on target, compared to only six including three on target for their opponents.
Against them, the West Ham players were able to be opportunistic by scoring at the start of the first half on a counter initiated by former Lyon player Lucas Paqueta and finished by Tomas Soucek (13‚Ä≤). The referees hesitated to validate it, checking if the ball had not gone out to the left of the goal on the pass before the goal but ended up awarding it.
In the second half, it was from a corner and thanks to a header from a former Arsenal player, Konstantinos Mavropanos, well helped by the post and the crossbar (55'), that West Ham made the break. The Hammers could even have finished off their opponents with a penalty in the dying seconds, saved by David Raya.
Mavropanos bends Arsenal again! üî¥
The former Gunner's header hits the bar and then the post before going into goal and it's 2-0 for West Ham ‚öíÔ∏è #WHUARS | #PremierLeague pic.twitter.com/skos017mBc
‚Äî CANAL+ Foot (@CanalplusFoot) December 28, 2023
Tottenham end their run at Brighton Having struggled away from home in recent weeks, the Hammers have made a very good move in the race for European qualification. West Ham are in sixth place in the Premier League table thanks to this win and are ahead of Manchester United.
Earlier in the evening, the other match of this 19th matchday of the Premier League saw Brighton surprise Tottenham in a very fast-paced match (4-2). Spurs, who were on a three-game winning streak, were unable to catch up after two goals from Jack Hinshelwood (11') and Joao Pedro (23' from the penalty spot).
They lost all hope after third and fourth goals from Pervis Estupinan (63‚Ä≤) and Joao Pedro (75‚Ä≤, again from the penalty spot), despite the reductions of the score by Alejo Veliz (81‚Ä≤) and Ben Davies (85‚Ä≤). Tottenham are in fifth place in the table.

author: Tyler Arnold
title: Catholic bishops sue Biden administration over abortion provisions in pregnant workers law | Catholic News Agency
text: Washington, D.C. Newsroom, May 24, 2024 / 16:08 pm The U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB) and other Catholic institutions [filed a lawsuit](https://becketnewsite.s3.amazonaws.com/20240522224428/2024-05-22-1-Complaint.pdf) against President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration over new rules that could require them to provide workplace accommodations for women who seek abortions. The lawsuit challenges [regulations issued](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/257405/biden-administration-to-mandate-employers-grant-leave-for-workers-to-obtain-abortions) by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) related to the implementation of the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act. The Catholic University of America (CUA) and two Catholic dioceses joined the USCCB in the lawsuit. Although the law itself does not mention abortion, the regulations would require that employers accommodate women for workplace limitations that arise from ‚Äúhaving or choosing not to have an abortion.‚Äù The law requires that employers provide reasonable accommodations to women who develop workplace limitations from pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions. The EEOC rules consider ‚Äúhaving or choosing not to have an abortion‚Äù as one of the related medical conditions covered under the legislation.

author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text: Lost Bible returned to slain USAAF airman from World War II [Saleen Martin](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7245115001/saleen-martin/) During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle. The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription ‚ÄúMay this keep you safe from harm." Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France. His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back. Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarch‚Äôs belongings. On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war. ‚ÄòI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages‚Äô Coogan‚Äôs uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.‚Äù Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums. ‚ÄúThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,‚Äù Coogan told USA TODAY. ‚ÄúThey would put it in their coat pockets ‚Ä¶ like the front breast pocket ‚Ä¶ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.‚Äù Lt. McKnight‚Äôs name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldn‚Äôt put it down, she recalled. ‚ÄúI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,‚Äù she said. She noticed that the Bible‚Äôs front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out. Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bible‚Äôs cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bible‚Äôs safe return to an address not too far away. Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called. ‚ÄúI was just hoping for the best,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúWe found out that number worked.‚Äù Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York. Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Force‚Äôs 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, [online records](https://rafbeaulieu.co.uk/honouring-the-airmen-of-raf-beaulieu/) show. Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fay‚Äôs husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life. ‚ÄúHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,‚Äù Coogan said. Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost. ‚ÄúHe didn't lose it,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale ‚Ä¶ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.‚Äù It ended up in Coogan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said. ‚ÄúThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,‚Äù she said.
